author: John Varlas
title: Week 10 prep football roundup
text:
Related Coverage White Station cruises; Brighton hands Munford first loss (1) Whitehaven 29, Collierville 6: Running and defense carried the Tigers (8-1, 5-1 Region 4-6A) as they tuned up for next week's showdown against Cordova. Darrion Cole had two short TD runs, Kylan Watkins ran for 172 yards and a score and Ray Booker had a 71-yard touchdown run as Whitehaven rolled up 312 yards on the ground. The Tiger defense meanwhile limited the Dragons (4-5, 2-4) to 124 yards and seven first downs.
(3) MUS 42, Craigmont 22: Bradley Foley ran for 123 yards and scored on runs of 1, 4, 8 and 5 yards — all in the first half — as the Owls (7-2) coasted past the Chiefs (1-8). Maurice Hampton opened the scoring with a 25-yard interception return while Steven Regis connected with Thomas Pickens on an 80-yard touchdown in the third quarter. Marshall Massie threw two touchdowns and ran for a third for Craigmont, but was intercepted three times.
(5) CBHS 67, Catholic 0: The Brothers (7-2) warmed up for next week's showdown against MUS by defeating the outmanned Chargers (1-8), holding the visitors to minus-60 yards rushing and minus-32 in total while recording two safeties. Walter Soefker scored on a 50-yard punt return in the first quarter while Will Ruth returned the second-half kickoff 90 yards for a score. Ruth later added a 27-yard touchdown run.
(7) Cordova 41, Houston 20: Devin Coleman threw three touchdown passes as the Wolves (8-1, 5-1 Region 4-6A) handled the Mustangs (1-8, 1-5). Coleman connected with Jarrius Anderson (26, 18) and Edward Johnson (16) while finishing with 283 yards. Shemar Collier scored on a 70-yard run for the Wolves. Carson Blackfan led Houston with 217 yards on just 15 carries, including an 85-yard touchdown run.
(8) Northpoint 41, Fayette-Ware 14: The Trojans — who are idle next week — wrapped up a 10-0 regular season by beating the Wildcats (4-5). Nelson Fabrizius had two short touchdown runs while Christian Saulsberry gained 120 yards on 16 carries and scored from 27 yards out. Garrison Bowling returned an interception 35 yards for another Trojans touchdown.
(9) St. George's 49, MAHS 14: Chase Hayden — Shelby County's top rusher — ran for 225 yards on just 12 carries as the Gryphons (8-1) rolled over the Lions (4-5). Hayden scored on runs of 29, 10 and 37 yards and caught a 7-yard touchdown pass from Ben Glass, who also threw a 55-yard touchdown to Corey Jones, a 58-yarder to Dawson Smith and a 12-yard touchdown run.
Arlington 47, Bartlett 30: The Tigers (6-3, 3-3 Region 4-6A) spotted the Panthers (3-6, 0-6) a 16-0 lead in the first quarter before roaring back. Tate Kolwyck threw touchdown passes of 9 yards to Justin Robbins, 6 yards to Everett Mitchell and 35 and 62 yards to Bryan Lewis. Keelon Webber ran for 168 yards and a score. Bartlett — which got all 392 of its yards on the ground — had scoring runs of 72 yards by Marquavious Weaver and 43 and 70 yards by LaMarcus Young.
Briarcrest 42, USJ 10: Charles Elliott ran for 190 yards and two scores as the Saints (5-4) handled the Bruins (7-2). Elliott opened the scoring with a 37-yarder in the first quarter and closed it with a 7-yarder in the fourth. Saints quarterback Hunter Hill ran for 121 yards and three touchdowns and also threw a 76-yard scoring pass to Jake Powers.
ECS 24, St. Benedict 21: Chandler Caughton hit a 19-yard field goal with 30 seconds left as ECS (3-6) edged St. Benedict (3-6). ECS quarterback Benton Garrison had a 30-yard touchdown run and scoring passes of 28 and 41 yards to Zach Genereaux. Colton Cochran had two touchdown runs in the second quarter for St. Benedict. Following the winning field goal, Ryan Pegg sealed it for ECS with an interception.
FACS 42, Kingsbury 7: The state's longest losing streak is now at 27 games as the Crusaders (5-4) got four touchdown passes from Jack Grissom, including 31 and 60 yards to Khari Henley, 5 yards to Spencer Powell and 31 yards to Jordan Hill. Nathan Carter had a 36-yard pick-six for FACS while Carson Penn returned a fumble 17 yards for a touchdown. The Falcons avoided the shutout on John Ndayambaje's 61-yard run.
Lausanne 48, Manassas 12: Mario Nolan-Dillard accounted for six touchdowns as the Lynx (6-3) rolled over the Tigers (2-7) on Senior Night. Dillard threw touchdown passes of 31 yards to Gray Clark, 5 and 51 yards to Adam Boyce and 33 yards to Jesse Neloms while scoring on a pair of 5-yard runs. James Smith had touchdown passes of 82 yards to London McGhee and 12 yards to LiDarrion Seymour for Manassas.
Ridgeway 56, Melrose 6: The Roadrunners (6-3) celebrated Homecoming with a dominant victory in a game that was moved to Kirby due to a power outage at Halle Stadium. Tyrique Sandusky threw touchdown passes of 36 yards to Vincent Taylor and 45 yards to Robert King while scoring on runs of 1 and 15 yards. Lilotis Walker ran for 182 yards and two touchdowns (13, 4) while Kundarrius Taylor closed the scoring with an 87-yard kickoff return. The Roadrunners top-ranked defense held Melrose (5-4) to 127 yards and just five first downs.
Tipton-Rosemark 41, West Memphis Christian 12: Darien Weakley's four touchdowns led the Rebels (3-6) over the Knights (2-8). Weakley threw scoring passes of 37 yards to A.J. Hightower, 7 yards to Tucker Pittman and 30 yards to Brody Starnes while scoring on a 1-yard run. Starnes also scored on a 45-yard interception return.
Trezevant 9, Mitchell 0: Cordarrian Richardson ran for 121 yards and gave the Bears (6-3) the only points they would need with a 9-yard run in the first quarter. Sammie Swing tacked on a 22-yard field goal while the Bears held Mitchell quarterback Wesley Bacchus to just 7 of 18 passing for 61 yards with four interceptions.
